dialogues.VALENTIN:
[1]Do you know who that is? That is the greatest man in the world. 
[2]Tolstoy does not approve of sexual relations. I know this. 
[3]This would not be a problem. I'm celibate. I'm also a strict vegetarian. 
[4]Believe me, since becoming a Tolstoyan, I have become so eager to learn, so comitted to discussing ideas, improving my very soul. 
[5]We? 
[6]In the name of truth and freedom. 
[7]Enemies? 
[8]She wouldn't open his private correspondence... 
[9]Please. 
[10]Anything? 
[11]Oh, goodness..It's a beautiful day. 
[12]I look forward to it. 
[13]Of course. 
[14]Just that...secrecy doesn't seem to me the essence of Tolstoy's thought. 
[15]Yes, I...I'll see you in the morning. 
[16]Come in. 
[17]That's very kind of you. 
[18]Last night. 
[19]He seems very sincere. 
[20]Thank you. Why are you laughing? 
[21]I said he seems very... Why? 
[22]I just arrived...What's your name? 
[23]Thank you for the tea. 
[24]Hello...hello... 
[25]I'm... I'm... Here is- 
[26]I'm sorry.     Sometimes I... 
[27]He told me about it...It's very exciting. 
[28]I'm very happy. You are very kind. I'm no one and you are... you are Leo Tolstoy and you ask me about my work. 
[29]It's a keystone of the movement. 
[30]
[31]It's your voice. It's wonderful. 
[32]Do your parents often speak to each other so...bluntly? 
[33]I'm sure she means well. 
[34]Your father is the greatest writer in the world. 
[35]I mean to say, I feel privileged to be here. It's an... honor. 
[36]I'm sorry. Sometimes I sneeze when I'm nervous. 
[37]It´s from your mother. She wants to see me. 
[38]Thank you, Countess... 
[39]I admire your husband immensely. 
[40]His ideas are beautiful...social justice...the idea...Don't you think? 
[41]Thank you. 
[42]Many times... twice. 
[43]He's given me an extraordinary opportunity. 
[44]I don't believe anyone wants to do that. 
[45]It's a very popular activity around your husband. 
[46]That may not be so easy. 
[47]He didn't need me this afternoon. 
[48]Leo Nikolayevich disapproves of women doing physical labor. Don't you find that reactionary? 
[49]Tolstoy's kind to everyone. 
[50]We talk about me. 
[51]He wants to know everything about me, my parents, my relations with women, my experience of god - 
[52]At school? 
[53]I see... 
[54]No...I appreciate your frankness 
[55]I don't. Not at all...I think sexual activity...how men and women combine their physical parts is completely neutral. 
[56]That's not fair 
[57]I'm going. 
[58]Yes. You know, I think that I... never mind. 
[59]A girl who died? 
[60]You shouldn't torture yourself. It was a long time ago. 
[61]I try to...you know, to... 
[62]Are you alright? 
[63]What do you mean? 
[64]It´s interesting. I think you would say..I mean, I´ve read where you say that the physical body isn´t real. That it´s all an illusion. 
[65]I...I don´t know. 
[66]Lilac? 
[67]I hope my work is pleasing to Leo Nikolayevich. 
[68]What do you mean? 
[69]It's not quite so obvious to me. 
[70]I do. 
[71]That's why I'm here. 
[72]Well, I think the Countess is very suspicios by nature. 
[73]I don´t think she likes you very much. 
[74]It´s a tone I´ve picked up. 
[75]Hello... Hello? 
[76]Masha? 
[77]Masha. 
[78]Masha. 
[79]What...what is it? 
[80]Wake up, wake up. 
[81]I want to ask you something..Say it again. 
[82]Why did you come to a place like this? 
[83]You don´t follow any of the rules. 
[84]What is it? 
[85]At the moment, I'm indisposed. 
[86]Tell him... I'll be down at once. 
[87]If I see her I will... 
[88]Let me go out first...give me five minutes... 
[89]What are you saying? 
[90]Masha. You are not supposed to smoke at Telyatinki. 
[91]It was difficult in front of the others. 
[92]I'm not sure I was conscious of God. 
[93]No... 
[94]You make it sound very simple. 
[95]I'm afraid I've hurt you, haven´t 
[96]She's here to question you about the new will. 
[97]She claims Leo Nikolayevich told her she could examine the draft. 
[98]It doesn't seem petty to me. 
[99]He`s her life. The work, in her mind, is theirs...together. 
[100]I'm talking about their history -- - simply that. 
[101]Nothing has happened. 
[102]I'll escort the Countess home and be back in time for supper. 
[103]It's nothing, really. 
[104]Masha is a friend. 
[105]A good friend. 
[106]I'm not annoyed. 
[107]Maybe I do. 
[108]Sorry, sorry, I'll... I didn't mean to scare you...Are you alright. 
[109]I came back as soon as I could. It was a strange day. Leo Nikolayevich,...I love to listen to him. I love nothing more... 
[110]But today I could hardly concentrate. 
[111]All I could think of was you. 
[112]What's wrong? 
[113]No. No. You didn´t confuse me..I was stupid. I was afraid, but I'm not afraid anymore. 
[114]I love you, Masha! 
[115]Masha... 
[116]Before the other night...I'd committed the act of copulation many times in my heart. 
[117]I think about you all the time. In my heart I´ve comitted the act of copulation many times. I just want to say...It was never like it was with you. 
[118]I hope you're feeling better. 
[119]I took singing lessons for years. I thought about a career in music. The only thing I lacked, in the end, was talent. I'm sorry about everything. 
[120]Really, I'm expected at Telyatinki. 
[121]I should go. 
[122]I thought it might be quieter, but- 
[123]Countess...Are you alright? 
[124]Is she alright? 
[125]It was terrible there today... between them. They loved each other so much, but you see what it becomes. 
[126]Masha, what´s the matter? 
[127]What? 
[128]This is him punishing us, punishing me for befriending Sofya Andreyevna. For not... This is Chertkov. 
[129]I don't care. You can't go away. I'll talk to him. I'll make him change his mind. i´m going to make you stay. 
[130]What? 
[131]You can´t leave Tolstoy. 
[132]Don't leave me, Masha... I need you. 
[133]I do. 
[134]Maybe we should get back. It'll be dark soon. May I ask you something that has nothing to do with work? 
[135]Do you love your wife? 
[136]I'm a secretary, after all. 
[137]I'm leaving Telyatinki. 
[138]I am going to Moscow. 
[139]Look, you say the movement's about love- 
[140]But I've never met mankind, only men and women, imperfect men, imperfect women. 
[141]I'm laughing because I didn't sneeze. 
[142]Yes, of course. 
[143]What? 
[144]Where will you go? 
[145]Do you want to go back? 
[146]I will. 
[147]I think so, yes. 
[148]I have this for you. 
[149]Countess! 
[150]Sasha, go back to the jetty. Here, let me help you. 
[151]I will. I will. Stay here. 
[152]I'm glad she can sleep. The pain subsides a little. 
[153]Ingenious. 
[154]I'm here. 
[155]I don't know if she's my girl. 
[156]I very much hope so. 
[157]I´ve told you she has promised she wouldn´t make any problems. But besides, where are we going? 
[158]Please move back. Please let him breath. Please give him some room. 
[159]The stationmaster says we may have his house for as long as we need it. There are no inns nearby, so we're lucky. 
[160]Hello, hello? Could you send a cable for me? 
[161]Tolstoy ill at Astapovo. Temperature high. Send it to Sofya Andreyevna, Yasnaya Polyana. 
[162]He wasn't well enough to travel. It's very cold. 
[163]Ready for what? 
[164]I'd like to send another cable. 
[165]At Astapovo. Stop. Tolstoy Ill. Stop. Heart breaking. Stop. Please Come.... That's it. 
[166]It goes to Masha...to Maria Filipovna Melinov, Moscow. Thank you. 
[167]Let me speak to her. 
[168]Countess! 
[169]Of course. But I'm not certain if it´s the best time, Countess. 
[170]Sofya Andreyevna... Stay back, stay back. 
[171]Let me take you back. 
[172]Yes, of course. 
[173]No, Countess, Don't worry. Not at all. 
[174]What is it? Dushan, what´s wrong? 
[175]You lied to him. 
[176]He wants to see her.    You heard him say it. 
[177]I don´t know, they´ve been married for 48 years. 
[178]She promised me- 
[179]They have a whole life togehter. Why do you have to deny that? 
[180]Keep the priest away- 
[181]No, you want an icon. You want to take photographs and give out postcards..You want people to kneel in front of an image you´ve created. But he doesn´t wanted that. He never wanted that, and it will give him no peace.  He wants to see her...let her come. 
[182]Oh, God. You exhaust me. 
[183]Tell me one thing. That image you want to create, just looks like you, doesn´t it? 
[184]Masha... 
[185]Masha...Masha...I'm so sorry he's gone. He´s gone. 
[186]I love you. I do. I love you. 
[187]Excuse me, Countess. This may not be the time, but- 
[188]Masha...this is Masha. 
[189]No, no. Not at all. I just wanted to say good bye. 
[190]God bless you, too.
dialogues.SOFYA:
[1]Why are we slowing down? 
[2]We're stopping. Why are we stopping? 
[3]Excuse me, why has the train stopped? 
[4]But if they block the track, the train can't go...YOU HAVE TO MAKE 
[5]Oh, they won't move. We are gonna die here. Leo, Leo, go and say something to them. It's the only way we are gonna get out of here. 
[6]Darling. 
[7]This is impossible! It really is! These people are parasites! Look... "Countess Tolstoy has become estranged from her husband. They barely speak." 
[8]You know who spreads all this rubbish.... 
[9]C'est la meme en France. They gossip about us in Paris... "They do not share a similar view of either religion or politics." Incroyable! 
[10]I think it's none of the world's business. 
[11]What are you doing? Don't do that. 
[12]Darling, where are you going? 
[13]Leovochka, why do you insist on dressing like that. 
[14]Like the man who looks after the sheep. 
[15]But it does offend me, because it offends reason. You're a Count, for God's sake. 
[16]Oh darling, I have something else to say. 
[17]These people have nothing. 
[18]It's not for lack of land that the muzhiks live in poverty. They have no will power and they drink too much. 
[19]It's all ridiculous. You think that poverty makes the peasants somehow morally superior. 
[20]Oh, I know all about the movement. 
[21]No, they'd spend it on drink and whores. 
[22]Stop scribbling! You all think he's Christ, don't you? He thinks he's Christ. 
[23]But what? 
[24]This is unbearable. No wonder I feel lonely. I'm surrounded by morrons. 
[25]Am I? I sit here and listen to this talk of love and God and equality, knowing full well that Count Generosity here is fully prepared to give away everything we have. 
[26]
[27]I see a fine young man before me. Clear eyes. Nice features, rather handsome in a peculiar way. 
[28]Call me Sofya Andreyevna. We don't stand on formality here, as you may have observed. Many young men ruin their looks by loose living. You're a real Tolstoyan, I can tell! 
[29]That's excellent. He likes that. 
[30]He's very grateful for the help you've been giving him. He told me so himself. I think it surprises him that a young man would be so diligent. When he was your age, he was whoring in the Caucasus. 
[31]He wrote it all down. He even gave me a copy, so I could read all the details... 
[32]You've read War and Peace? 
[33]When he was writing it, long before Chertkov created that monstrosity at Telyatinki, before all this "new religion" and revolutionary nonsense... What do you think of Chertkov, by the way? 
[34]But you see what a fool he is, a self-serving puritanical idiot. I have to say, it's been extremely pleasant since they've locked him in his house. 
[35]When my husband was writing it, in the mid-sixties, he'd bring me pages to re-copy everyday. I was the only one who could read his handwriting. I could read his intentions, too. Afternoons, we'd drink tea and discuss changes. "Natasha wouldn't say that to Prince Andrey," or "Pierre's too simple here. He's not stupid." 
[36]But I don't count anymore. 
[37]You must help me, Valentin Fedorovich. I want only what is best for my husband and my family. I could tolerate the situation if it only concerned me What I can not do is sit back while they steal my children's inheritance. Do you know I was the only person. I could understand his intention. 
[38]I have a little gift for you 
[39]It's a diary.  Everyone should always keep a diary. 
[40]You're teasing me, but I trust you'll write the truth. 
[41]Nonsense. You've been listening to your friends at Telyatinki... Write what you see. That's always the place to begin. What. You. See. 
[42]More tea? 
[43]He'll try again to convince your father to change his will. 
[44]To give the copyright as "a gift to humanity."...the reptile. 
[45]You're a fine son, darling. None of this make believe chastity and made up religion. I wish all my children had turned out like you. 
[46]Chertkov's notions of virtuous behavior are calculated to destroy me. 
[47]There is nothing more pathetic than impoverished aristocrats. 
[48]Vladimir Grigorevich, what a surprise. 
[49]And I'm happy to make you happy...always. 
[50]I'm fine...now that you're home. 
[51]Did I really? I don't believe it. Not you. I'm your little bird. You know the sounds I make. 
[52]It brought you back to me. 
[53]Come out of the dark... where I can see you. 
[54]Look at me. This is who I am. This is what you married. We're older, maybe we're old, but I'm still your little chicken You're still my big cock. 
[55]Let me make you crow. 
[56]Let me make you sing. 
[57]Do you love me? 
[58]Good morning, my darling? Do you mind if I join you? 
[59]It's quite insane, my darling. Everyone is making fun of you. 
[60]Even the muzhiks. I heard them laughing in the barn. 
[61]I don't want to ruin last night. 
[62]Laughing about the fact that you've developed a senile crush on a fat middle aged flatterer. Your passion for Chertkov has become a standing joke. 
[63]But it's not amusing, darling. It's sick. It's not normal. You hang on his every word. 
[64]You have nothing in common. You are a genius. He's a sycophant and a pervert. 
[65]He is using you. You just can't seem to see it. 
[66]That bold, obese, idiotic man. You treat him... 
[67]Do you love me, Lyovochka? 
[68]Then why would you betray me? 
[69]Because of the will? 
[70]The new will. 
[71]Does Chertkov have it? 
[72]But that's why he's come back. You talk about it, you and your boyfriend. You plan for it. You have no heart for the people who really love you. You'd rather be seduced by charlatans and deluded by flatterers, all in the name of love....You can't even love your own children. You can't even love me. 
[73]Tell me where it is? 
[74]Then, promise me there never will be. 
[75]Tomorrow, I'll go to the Station and lie down on the track. Tolstoy's wife becomes Anna Karenina herself! See how the papers will like that! 
[76]And I'm happy to make you happy...always. 
[77]Your moustache is... 
[78]Let me get to the point. Vladimir Grigorivich, I don't wish to be your enemy. I'm delighted that my husband has a friend who understands and shares his ideals. All I want is what's reasonable - an opportunity to evaluate the new will. If you agree, I'm sure we can be friends. 
[79]Leo Nikolayevich has agreed, hasn't he Val- 
[80]Very well. 
[81]Yes. Valentin Fedorovich...are you coming back to the house with me? 
[82]Have you been keeping something from me? How delightful. 
[83]We've become close friends, I think. Tell me everything, dear boy. I love a romance. 
[84]A young woman in your life is nothing? 
[85]A lover? 
[86]That sounds serious enough. 
[87]I don't mean to annoy you. 
[88]You forget that I'm an experienced reader. I can read your face, every letter. It's beautifully clear. Do you love her? 
[89]Not something they'd understand, these so called disciples of my husband. They've never understood a word he's written. What do any of them know about love? 
[90]Ivan, who's wearing that awful perfume? 
[91]How dare you? 
[92]You're all plotting against me. In my own house, too. I bear you thirteen children. How can you betray me like this? Someone help me up. 
[93]Give everything you've got to him, your fat little catamite. "What will it be, my dearest dear, my Vladimir Grigorivich? My wife's heart on a platter? Her kidneys? With salt? But of course, my dear Chertkov, whatever pleases you. The china. The estate. Permanent copyright on everything I've ever written? Anything for you, my love." 
[94]Give me that. Give it to me, you little weasel. 
[95]Now... 
[96]You! Don't think you deceive me for one little moment! I know exactly what you're doing. I want to see the will. It's my right, in the name of god. 
[97]You.   I'm afraid of you. 
[98]Tell them anything you like. Go ahead. Ruin us. 
[99]Why can't my husband see you for what you are? 
[100]Do you like the opera? 
[101]This aria is very beautiful.. It is about a woman who is abandoned by the man who loves her...Everyone is very moved by that...in the opera. 
[102]Sit down, Valentin. 
[103]No, no, no. Enjoy your dinner. We've had a disagreement. No more than any other married couple. 
[104]Of course... 
[105]Why should it be easy? I'm the work of your life. You're the work of mine. Its what love is. 
[106]Everything with him is hysterics 
[107]Go? Where? 
[108]Go where? 
[109]Then go! Go! Anywhere you please! 
[110]I hate you. I hate what you've become. 
[111]You'll destroy me. 
[112]My back. My back... I'm hurting. 
[113]Ya...your...your...I can´t remember now...Yo, what did I say? What did you mean? 
[114]Lyovochka? Prozeveskeny wants to purchase the rights to your work after your death. 
[115]Don't be silly. They've offered one million rubles. 
[116]How can you not be pleased? 
[117]Where are you going? 
[118]Splendid...while your wretched family is left to starve. 
[119]But you're always first to the trough...always have been. 
[120]How could you do this to me? 
[121]You hurt me again and again. You take little pieces of me until I become nothing. I don't know who I am anymore. I read your diary. I know what you've done. 
[122]No! Give me the gun! 
[123]You're a liar. Liar! 
[124]So, he's gone. For good. 
[125]
[126]Let me die. Please. Why would you rob me of that? 
[127]Ivan, go to the station. Find out which train the master took. 
[128]They've all gone 
[129]You're writing to your girl. That's lovely. 
[130]But you believe you'll see her again. 
[131]Yes. Refuse to believe in the end of love. Do all you can to prevent it... 
[132]I know you know where he is, Valentin. 
[133]I won't ask you to betray his trust...but I need you to go to him. I do. I have to see him. I have to talk to him. I won't make a scene. Promise him that. I must see him. 
[134]Tell him we've received an apologetic letter from your father..very embarrassed. We expect him back any day... 
[135]Yes, that's a lie. 
[136]We must leave at once. 
[137]We'll rent a train. 
[138]Don't say irrelevant things, Andrey. It's unbecoming. Contact someone. I'll go and pack. 
[139]I'll see what I can do, father. 
[140]I want to see my husband. 
[141]I want to see him. Now! 
[142]Valentin...Will you help me?    I have to see him. Please. 
[143]It is.   It's the right time for me. 
[144]I want to see my husband. 
[145]But he's not too weak to see you. Not too weak to see that... 
[146]I am the leper outside the gate, while he sleeps with the devil himself. 
[147]Is that true? 
[148]Have you told him I nearly drowned in the pond? 
[149]What did he say? 
[150]He'd be upset? 
[151]I want to see him. He's not your husband.   He's my husband. 
[152]And you are a stone-hearted bitch of a daughter. 
[153]I lost five children. Why couldn't one of them have been you? 
[154]Valentin, will you take me back? 
[155]I've behaved badly, haven't I? 
[156]Has he asked for me? 
[157]Lyovochka! 
[158]Please forgive me, my darling! 
[159]I'm a fool.. I'm a selfish woman. But I love you. Please believe me. Please understand me. Please forgive me for all my weakness and badness. Please! Please! Love me! 
[160]Was I shouting? 
[161]You don't speak, but I hear you. 
[162]"Do you love me, Lyovochka." "Never stopped, my little bird." "And you will never stop" "Never." "Nor ever leave me again." "Never, ever again. "Good...good... let's go home" 
[163]Please forgive me if I cry a little now. 
[164]It's alright. What happens from now on... it will never really matter. Not really. Everything's finished. 
[165]Dushan, could you tell them your great friend is gone? 
[166]My husband needs no justification. Besides, it´s been enough talking as it is. Thank you, father. 
[167]Valentin... and who's this... 
[168]This is your girl. Good. Good. Is there anything I can do for you? 
[169]Yes...Good bye, good bye.     God bless you. 
[170]Well, I'm ready to go now. Why aren´t we moving? Can't someone make it move? 
[171]Oh!
dialogues.TOLSTOY:
[1]I have seen your banner. And I´ve heard what you say. You think I´m the hope of Russia, do you? Well, that´s not true. You are the hope of Russia. The hope of all the world. You say, you want a new way to live? Well, you are not gonna find it making a fuss over me. So, I suggest that you get on with your work and let a poor old men get on with his. 
[2]Nothing's working... Hand me my other boot, my friend, will you? 
[3]It doesn't matter. If my heart had stopped beating, I'd still go riding today. 
[4]Peut-etre. You think that's inaccurate? 
[5]Dushan Petrovich, you're scribbling again? 
[6]Riding with Sasha. Don't expect us for lunch. 
[7]What do you mean? 
[8]It's not meant to offend you. 
[9]I doubt it not, my dear. 
[10]These people are bandits. 
[11]They come into my house and arrest a man whose only crime is to express a view of life saner than that which prevails. 
[12]Of course, I'm the guilty one. I reject the Orthodox church. I condemn the established order and I make no secret of it. 
[13]Sasha! 
[14]I'm glad you're here. So glad. 
[15]God bless you. 
[16]Vladimir Grigorevich has already written about you at length. I need your help badly. The manifesto against the government is hard work. They commit their idiotic abuses faster than I can catalogue them...and the new book... 
[17]I've become convinced that all the world's religions have a single organizing principle. Can you guess what it is? Love! Love! Simple... Now, I want to talk about you. How are you? How was your journey? Come, sit down. 
[18]You know, I was born on this sofa... 
[19]Sit. Sit. 
[20]Myself, my brother, my children, at least five or six of them, right here. Now, I've read your essays. How`s your work progressing? 
[21]My boy, what is it? I upset you in some way. Was it the sofa? It's only a sofa. 
[22]You rest for a moment and I'll fetch you a glass of tea. Rest, because there's work for both of us together. 
[23]I'm not suggesting they be given land. Private property is the root of the problem... We should be giving ours away. 
[24]I believe that wealth corrupts us all, yes I do. 
[25]If the peasants had money, they wouldn't surround themselves, as we do, with footmen costing ten rubles a month. 
[26]Valentin Fedorovich, do you think fifty years from now, people will eat while grown men walk around and wait on them hand and foot? 
[27]You keep going on like that...Why do you think we should profit from the work I´m doing which is only meant for the sake of the people. 
[28]It's tiresome. Another remarkable invention will supercede it. 
[29]Please excuse me. 
[30]Oh, that´s better. That´s nice. Very nice indeed. 
[31]I couldn't write. I was distracted I think...I had a dream last night, about a Tartar girl I knew in the war. 
[32]No, no...A girl I had sexual intercourse with... Sometimes we did it twice a day. 
[33]God bless...I've never forgotten our time together, the position of our bodies, the taste of her... 
[34]Torture? You are a virgin, aren't you. 
[35]To be what, a good Tolstoyan? 
[36]You see, I myself am not a very good Tolstoyan. You should think twice about asking my advice about anything... Torture... 
[37]Kalya, her name was...She's an old woman now, white hair, old body like me. She'd hardly remember my name, I suspect. She may even be dead.  Do you think that meant something? 
[38]I mean that little romance. Was there some meaning to it? 
[39]I say lots of things. What do you say? What do you think? 
[40]I don´t know, either. 
[41]Smell that... 
[42]Precisely. It's lilac. The smell's stronger when the sun goes down. 
[43]I've enjoyed myself, my boy. 
[44]My dear, dear man. 
[45]An old man is a very ugly thing. 
[46]My dear boy. Come and kiss me. 
[47]Now, who is this? Maria Filipovna. 
[48]You're both looking so well. Life here at Telyatinki obviously agrees with you. 
[49]God bless you, boy. What are you nervous about, now? Sit down. Sit down. 
[50]Dear Masha, Valentin tells me you're the great treasure of Telyatinki. He claims you're a very gifted teacher. 
[51]What do you mean? 
[52]Forgive him. He can't help it. He's a better Tolstoyan than I am. 
[53]No, my dear, I'll go alone. 
[54]Sofya. 
[55]Sofya, are you ill? 
[56]It's no good, you know, all this. You frightened everyone. 
[57]That was some sort of love call? 
[58]Why? Why? Why, do you do it? We live in the country and you insist on making it an opera house. What's wrong with a little peace now and then? 
[59]I do. 
[60]Of course, my dear. 
[61]What are you talking about? 
[62]About what? 
[63]Laughing about what?
